Utt's selection as the new
chaplain for the Johns Hopkins

be terrific."

Council Concerns
We have not seriously commented on the
Student Council this semester with the exception of the HOP and the Housing Committee. Anyone who attends weekly Council meetings would not be surprised by this.
These meetings generally run smoothly and
one may sense a complacent attitude. Indeed, members rarely vote against a motion.
They are usually passed unanimously with
an occasional abstention.
This is not to say that Council has been
ineffective this year. It would be more correct to argue the reverse. Student Council has
been working toward bridging the corrununciation gaps at Hopkins and members seem
dedicated to improving student life here.
This past Wednesday night was unusual,
however. Early in the meeting, the standard
Council proceedings took place. President
Jon Lana expressed his weekly concern that
the Council office hours be kept. The committees reported their activities. It seemed
another traditional Council meeting.
Then something different happened. Jon
Lana presented a resolution concerning the
commitment of the administration to future
student involvement in WJHU-FM, the
formerly student-run radio station at
Hopkins.
The fact that a resolution was offered is
not surprising; Council commonly issues
general resoluions involving timely student

concerns. Nor was the content of the resolution surprising; the proposal was composed
to communicate to the administration in a
non-provoking manner that students expect
a follow-up on the alleged commitment to
student involvement at the station. The
Council is a pragmatic organization; they
fully realize that they must be civil to the administration to get anything done.
What was surprising was the Council's
response. Based on the discussion, it seemed several members were offended by the
tone of the resolution: "The Student Council...strongly and wholeheartedly supports
the...commitment of the administration to
continued student involvement in WJHU..."
Representatives felt this was not a true
description of students' feelings. Students
were angry about the way the administration
handled the radio station transition. If a
resolution was to be offered, they claimed,
it should outline specific student involvement
objectives rather than giving the University
a "blank check" in the interpretation of the
term "student involvement."
We agree. Student involvement at WJHU
is too important an issue to be relegated to
a resolution without real substance. Yet, the.
Council's rejection of this resolution is not
enough; a new proposal should be written
and approved which is more specific to the
problem.

named Joshua, who had 10

Diagnosing Infant Botulism
Physicians at The Johns
Hopkins Hospital have
developed a new test for quickly diagnosing infant botulism,
a potentially fatal bacterial
disease that affects babies in the
first few months of life,
• Not only does the new procedure reduce the time required
for diagnosis and the start of
life-saving treatment, it also
eliminates the need for live mice
currently used in diagnostic
tests. The new test is the
outgrowth of studies funded by
The Johns Hopkins Center for
Alternatives to Animal Testing.
A description of the new test,
developed by physicians in the
Departments of Pediatrics and
Medicine at Hopkins, appears
in a recent issue of the Journal
of Clinical Microbiology.
Infant botulism is a newlyrecognized form of the
.disorder, first described in
1976. that occurs when children

ingest harmful organisms,
found in soil or foods. Symptoms include weakness, constipation, poor feeding and
muscle laxity. Rapid diagnosis
is useful to avoid unnecessary
tests and treatment.
It is estimated there are 100
cases of infant botulism each
year in the United States,
although there is evidence the
condition may be underdiagnosed. Infant botulism
now outranks food-borne cases
as the most common form of
botulism in the United States.
More commonly seen in adults,
food-borne botulism has a
quicker onset because the toxin, rather than the bacteria, is
ingested by the victim.
Currently, diagnosis requires
specimens from patients with
suspected botulism to be sent to
the U. S. Centers for Disease
Control or other specialized

laboratories where laborious
and time-consuming animal
tests take from 10 to 14 days.
The new test could be performed in any hospital laboratory in
as little as six hours and may actually be more reliable, in some
cases, than the conventional
test.
The new test uses and enzyme marker test known as
ELISA (short for enzymelinked immunosorbent assay).
The ELISA test uses an enzyme
attached to an antibody that
reacts with the toxin in the patient's stool specimen. The test
result is a color reaction that
can be read by the naked eye.
Although the new test has
also been used in two cases of
adults with botulism, the investigators caution that more
research needs to be done to
provide definitive conclusions
on the test's reliability for this
form of the disease.

U2's Unforgettable Fire: Eno Lends a Hand
by Peter Oehlkers
When I first heard the strains
of "Pride (In the Name of
Love)" coming from my radio,
I was really happy—it didn't
sound like anything on War.
Not that War was a terribly bad
album—it was fine on its own
terms, but it just didn't sound
like the U2 I had loved so much
on their first two albums, Boy
and October. War turned U2
into a "98-Rock band"—guitar
hero rock. So I was relieved to
hear Pride—like most of War,
commercial as hell but with the
emphasis on rhythm and
melody instead of The Guitar.
Still, I was very surprised at
what I heard on "The Unforgettable Fire." Throw all
those guitar-rock labels out the
window, U2 is more atmospheric and quietly melodic
than ever. Nor is this another
political album: only two songs
come close to being protests:

"Pride" and "MLK"(Martin
Luther King). Furthermore,
this is not the overtly "Christian" album many were
expecting—that much is buried
in vague biblical allusions.
What this album is is a Brian
Eno collaboration album. Eno
and his current work-mate,
Daniel Lanois, produced the
album and it shows. Eno, Mr.
Ambient himself, has returned
U2 to their rhythmic/atmospheric roots but unfortunately he may have overdone
it. The recording itself is very
beautiful, but in making it so
Eno has smoothed down the
rough edges that made U2 so
exciting. The album also suffers
from Eno's electronic overembellishments. He actually
makes U2 sound like Electric
Light Orchestra on at least one
occasion ("Indian Summer
Sky").
Other
Enomanifestations are: the song
"4th of July," an instrumental

that could easily have been on
any of his "ambient" records;
and his occasional success in
turning the Edge into a Robert
Fripp-like
experimental
guitarist.
This is not to say that this is
not a U2 album. The Edge's
distinctive guitar style is still
very much in evidence and his
trademark backing vocals still
pop up occasionally; Bono is
still one of the most affecting
vocalists in the business,
whether slipping into a falsetto
or in a full yell; and Larry
Mullen and Adam Clayton still
remain a more-than-solid
rhythmic section. There are
some major changes, though
some of them are due as much
to Eno's production as to a
change in band philosophy.
There is a general move away
from exciting, dancy rock and
towards mood and melody: a
move away from the likes of "I
Will Follow" and "Sunday

Bloody Sunday" and towards
songs like Boy's "The Ocean"
and War's "40." This album's
title track and the song "Elvis
Presley and America" are
among the prettiest songs U2
has ever recorded.
There is also a marked increase in lyrical vagueness. You
get the mood of the songs quite
handily but usually you really
don't know what's going on.
Elemental imagery abounds—
there are many references to
Fire, Rain, Earth, Sky, etc.—
folky imagery that Eno's electronic production actually
works against. This lyrical
vagueness, coupled with the
general moodiness of the
music, makes for a beautiful atmospheric record but at the
same time for an album
distinctly lacking in any real
emotional directness—a quality that was previously one of
U2's most winning.
The Unforgettable Fire is not

as much a departure for U2 as
an inevitability. The band that
started out on Boy as a rock
band desperately wanting to
grow up has matured (with the
help of the Eno/Lanois production)into a refined atmospheric
band, and an atmospheric
album is usually better to go to
sleep to than party to. Still, the
album is not really as boring as
it may have appeared from this
review. Bono, at his most impressive vocally on this album,
does a good job of keeping the
proceedings alive. There is also
a driving dance tune, "Wire,"
and of course the single, "Pride
(In the Name of Love)," which
is probably one of their best
songs ever. I still get the overwhelming feeling that U2 has
grown up too soon, though.
Here's hoping for a nice big
regression (and a more sympathetic producer) for the next
album.

Council Concerns
We have not seriously commented on the
Student Council this semester with the exception of the HOP and the Housing Committee. Anyone who attends weekly Council meetings would not be surprised by this.
These meetings generally run smoothly and
one may sense a complacent attitude. Indeed, members rarely vote against a motion.
They are usually passed unanimously with
an occasional abstention.
This is not to say that Council has been
ineffective this year. It would be more correct to argue the reverse. Student Council has
been working toward bridging the corrununciation gaps at Hopkins and members seem
dedicated to improving student life here.
This past Wednesday night was unusual,
however. Early in the meeting, the standard
Council proceedings took place. President
Jon Lana expressed his weekly concern that
the Council office hours be kept. The committees reported their activities. It seemed
another traditional Council meeting.
Then something different happened. Jon
Lana presented a resolution concerning the
commitment of the administration to future
student involvement in WJHU-FM, the
formerly student-run radio station at
Hopkins.
The fact that a resolution was offered is
not surprising; Council commonly issues
general resoluions involving timely student

concerns. Nor was the content of the resolution surprising; the proposal was composed
to communicate to the administration in a
non-provoking manner that students expect
a follow-up on the alleged commitment to
student involvement at the station. The
Council is a pragmatic organization; they
fully realize that they must be civil to the administration to get anything done.
What was surprising was the Council's
response. Based on the discussion, it seemed several members were offended by the
tone of the resolution: "The Student Council...strongly and wholeheartedly supports
the...commitment of the administration to
continued student involvement in WJHU..."
Representatives felt this was not a true
description of students' feelings. Students
were angry about the way the administration
handled the radio station transition. If a
resolution was to be offered, they claimed,
it should outline specific student involvement
objectives rather than giving the University
a "blank check" in the interpretation of the
term "student involvement."
We agree. Student involvement at WJHU
is too important an issue to be relegated to
a resolution without real substance. Yet, the.
Council's rejection of this resolution is not
enough; a new proposal should be written
and approved which is more specific to the
problem.

There once was a little boy
named Joshua, who had 10
matchbox cars. He and his
friends used to play with them
all the time in Joshua's room,
which was in the basement of
his very large house. After a
while, Joshua and his friends
started getting very bored with
the 10 matchbox cars. So one
day when Joshua's Uncle Steve
came over to visit, he expressed his boredom. Uncle Steve
asked Joshua, "How would
you like 25,000 matchbox
cars?"Joshua's eyes widened.
It was like a dream come true!
Uncle Steve said that in order
to have 25,000 matchbox cars,
Joshua would have to move to
a new room, because his old
one wasn't going to be big
enough to handle all those cars.
Joshua's parents were
already having construction
done on the house so they
decided to give Joshua a brand
new room, which could hold
25,000 matchbox cars and give
him and his playmates room.
While this was being done,
Joshua had no place to stay.

Uncle Steve said that Aunt
Beatrice would be more than
willing to take him. Poor Aunt
Bea suffered from a form of
motion sickness and therefore
Joshua would have to leave his
20 cars behind. Since Joshua
was anticipating that soon he
would have 25,000 cars, he
reluctantly consented.
Uncle Steve promised Joshua
that his room would be ready in
a couple of days. So Joshua
waited. And waited. And
played with imaginary cars.
And waited. He finally asked
Aunt Bea to ask Uncle Steve
about his room and his cars.
Uncle Steve, who had been
away for a while, told Joshua
that the architects were still
working on the plans, and that
it would take a few more days.
He also told Joshua that the
room would be so large and
have so many matchbox car
roads that he hired a traffic
manager to watch over the cars
and Joshua and his friends to
make sure everything ran
smoothly.
Uncle Steve promised Joshua
that he and his friends would
still be able to play with the

matchbox cars, but that the
traffic manager would prevent
accidents and other things.
So Joshua, a little disheartened, waited. And waited. And
started thinking of other things
to play with. And waited.
Finally Uncle Steve called and
told Joshua he had great news.
He and the architects and
Joshua's parents had finally
finished the plans. Uncle Steve
said they'd be using all the
latest technology, including
"automated matchbox car
tracks, with working traffic
lights and everything". Uncle
Steve was excited that he would
have such a show piece.
Joshua, now visibly upset
because all he wanted to do was
play with his matchbox cars
with his friends like he used to,
told Uncle Steve that he was going to ride his Big Wheel
around the yard for a while.
Uncle Steve told Joshua, "I'm
sorry you can't ride your Big
Wheel around the yard now,
because we're having a big party and you're not big enough to
attend."
Joshua took his Big Wheel
and rode away . . .

Diagnosing Infant Botulism
Physicians at The Johns
Hopkins Hospital have
developed a new test for quickly diagnosing infant botulism,
a potentially fatal bacterial
disease that affects babies in the
first few months of life,
• Not only does the new procedure reduce the time required
for diagnosis and the start of
life-saving treatment, it also
eliminates the need for live mice
currently used in diagnostic
tests. The new test is the
outgrowth of studies funded by
The Johns Hopkins Center for
Alternatives to Animal Testing.
A description of the new test,
developed by physicians in the
Departments of Pediatrics and
Medicine at Hopkins, appears
in a recent issue of the Journal
of Clinical Microbiology.
Infant botulism is a newlyrecognized form of the
.disorder, first described in
1976. that occurs when children

ingest harmful organisms,
found in soil or foods. Symptoms include weakness, constipation, poor feeding and
muscle laxity. Rapid diagnosis
is useful to avoid unnecessary
tests and treatment.
It is estimated there are 100
cases of infant botulism each
year in the United States,
although there is evidence the
condition may be underdiagnosed. Infant botulism
now outranks food-borne cases
as the most common form of
botulism in the United States.
More commonly seen in adults,
food-borne botulism has a
quicker onset because the toxin, rather than the bacteria, is
ingested by the victim.
Currently, diagnosis requires
specimens from patients with
suspected botulism to be sent to
the U. S. Centers for Disease
Control or other specialized

laboratories where laborious
and time-consuming animal
tests take from 10 to 14 days.
The new test could be performed in any hospital laboratory in
as little as six hours and may actually be more reliable, in some
cases, than the conventional
test.
The new test uses and enzyme marker test known as
ELISA (short for enzymelinked immunosorbent assay).
The ELISA test uses an enzyme
attached to an antibody that
reacts with the toxin in the patient's stool specimen. The test
result is a color reaction that
can be read by the naked eye.
Although the new test has
also been used in two cases of
adults with botulism, the investigators caution that more
research needs to be done to
provide definitive conclusions
on the test's reliability for this
form of the disease.

U2's Unforgettable Fire: Eno Lends a Hand
by Peter Oehlkers
When I first heard the strains
of "Pride (In the Name of
Love)" coming from my radio,
I was really happy—it didn't
sound like anything on War.
Not that War was a terribly bad
album—it was fine on its own
terms, but it just didn't sound
like the U2 I had loved so much
on their first two albums, Boy
and October. War turned U2
into a "98-Rock band"—guitar
hero rock. So I was relieved to
hear Pride—like most of War,
commercial as hell but with the
emphasis on rhythm and
melody instead of The Guitar.
Still, I was very surprised at
what I heard on "The Unforgettable Fire." Throw all
those guitar-rock labels out the
window, U2 is more atmospheric and quietly melodic
than ever. Nor is this another
political album: only two songs
come close to being protests:

"Pride" and "MLK"(Martin
Luther King). Furthermore,
this is not the overtly "Christian" album many were
expecting—that much is buried
in vague biblical allusions.
What this album is is a Brian
Eno collaboration album. Eno
and his current work-mate,
Daniel Lanois, produced the
album and it shows. Eno, Mr.
Ambient himself, has returned
U2 to their rhythmic/atmospheric roots but unfortunately he may have overdone
it. The recording itself is very
beautiful, but in making it so
Eno has smoothed down the
rough edges that made U2 so
exciting. The album also suffers
from Eno's electronic overembellishments. He actually
makes U2 sound like Electric
Light Orchestra on at least one
occasion ("Indian Summer
Sky").
Other
Enomanifestations are: the song
"4th of July," an instrumental

that could easily have been on
any of his "ambient" records;
and his occasional success in
turning the Edge into a Robert
Fripp-like
experimental
guitarist.
This is not to say that this is
not a U2 album. The Edge's
distinctive guitar style is still
very much in evidence and his
trademark backing vocals still
pop up occasionally; Bono is
still one of the most affecting
vocalists in the business,
whether slipping into a falsetto
or in a full yell; and Larry
Mullen and Adam Clayton still
remain a more-than-solid
rhythmic section. There are
some major changes, though
some of them are due as much
to Eno's production as to a
change in band philosophy.
There is a general move away
from exciting, dancy rock and
towards mood and melody: a
move away from the likes of "I
Will Follow" and "Sunday

Bloody Sunday" and towards
songs like Boy's "The Ocean"
and War's "40." This album's
title track and the song "Elvis
Presley and America" are
among the prettiest songs U2
has ever recorded.
There is also a marked increase in lyrical vagueness. You
get the mood of the songs quite
handily but usually you really
don't know what's going on.
Elemental imagery abounds—
there are many references to
Fire, Rain, Earth, Sky, etc.—
folky imagery that Eno's electronic production actually
works against. This lyrical
vagueness, coupled with the
general moodiness of the
music, makes for a beautiful atmospheric record but at the
same time for an album
distinctly lacking in any real
emotional directness—a quality that was previously one of
U2's most winning.
The Unforgettable Fire is not

as much a departure for U2 as
an inevitability. The band that
started out on Boy as a rock
band desperately wanting to
grow up has matured (with the
help of the Eno/Lanois production)into a refined atmospheric
band, and an atmospheric
album is usually better to go to
sleep to than party to. Still, the
album is not really as boring as
it may have appeared from this
review. Bono, at his most impressive vocally on this album,
does a good job of keeping the
proceedings alive. There is also
a driving dance tune, "Wire,"
and of course the single, "Pride
(In the Name of Love)," which
is probably one of their best
songs ever. I still get the overwhelming feeling that U2 has
grown up too soon, though.
Here's hoping for a nice big
regression (and a more sympathetic producer) for the next
album.
